Summary

ID: 49881 Status: Submitted
Entered By: Tom Sawyer Comparison: Average
Entered: Event Type: Grand Prix
Observed: City: Nuuk
Language: English Country: Greenland
Reviewer: Tom Sawyer Subject: Yasser Haddad
Reviewer Level: 3 Existing Level: 4
Reviewer Role: Team Lead Subject Role: Head Judge
Type: Evaluation
Strengths: (This is a 2013 review)

I really liked the schedules you gave us, with complete information about the teams' show up times as well as the team task schedule, which clarifies a lot of stuff. It also makes sure that all major tasks are being handled, since every team knows what it's responsible for. The planned breaks worked out just right. Even if we had all deck-checks teams one one full-round break each during the first 3 rounds, we managed to deal with all decklists in time, having located all of them (including the 40+ missing sleep-in ones) and counted all of them by mid-round 3, the goal being start of round 4. This worked because about half of your staff was on deck-checks teams and only lightly used for floor coverage; compare with GP Kaluqjuaq where there was only one DC team sorting/counting each round and counting was not complete until mid-round 4.

On Friday, you were in charge of getting everyone together for Moishe Goldstein's L3 test. While the people involved had various delays, I was stressing a bit and you did an excellent job of calming me down. This may not seem very significant, but be assured that it was and that I appreciated it!
Areas for Improvement: While the printed judge schedule was complete, it had the wrong starting time (9:30 instead of 10:00 advertised by the TO online). This led to some confusion inside my team (I like giving breakfast time to my team members if briefings and tasks are done). If the error had been the opposite, it could have led to wrong information given to players and players missing at the seat-all. In short, please double-check this kind of info.

When we were dealing with the late decklists, a lot of them were coming from players who had sent them to the wrong e-mail address. This was mostly a TO issue (they didn't have access to their other e-mail account and didn't send reminders to registered players) and I feel like judges were here to mitigate the issue. We did collect a large number of decklists (thanks to Judit Polgar's team), however a few still arrived during round 3. When presented with the facts, the judge who was telling you that he was holding one such decklist. You decided to give that player a Tardiness GL. When asked for confirmation and what about the remaining such lists, you basically didn't look further and just said to GL that particular player. This makes me feel like a random scape goat was chosen and no particular effort was made to ensure 1) that what the player did was GL-worthy, 2) that it wasn't the TO's fault, 3) that players were treated equally. Basically, I think we are lucky that this player didn’t communicate with the other late ones, as that could have given some uproar! In summary, I really dislike such a random penalty.

On one decklist, a player who was playing Patriot listed "4 Turn." You decided to give the player a D/DLP game loss on the grounds of Turn to Slag being in the format. However, the grounds to downgrade this are multiple:
- Turn to Slag is really not the card that would jump to people's minds when reading the list (most people familiar with Standard would immediately identify it as "Turn/Burn")
- Turn is a legitimate card that can be searched on the Gatherer
- Some online articles have bad handling of split cards, making only one half appear
- A recent rules change has each half of a split card have a complete card name (for example on Meddling Mage you can name "Turn"), this could be confused for rules about tournaments as well
- a discussion happened a few days earlier where Confucius concluded it was fair to downgrade this particular case,
Would you believe the player if he actually was playing Turn to Slag? I would have strong suspicions of cheating in that case (though not very effective, but that's another story). Also, what if the player was playing mono-blue ? He could only cast Turn and have valid arguments for listing just that. I think that the reasons for downgrading were numerous enough that you should have allowed that.
Comments: This was mostly a solid GP from your part. Be wary however of not becoming an IPG-on-legs and please listen to arguments when given to you :). Even if you take your own decisions, which is fine, please take the time to explain why you wouldn't follow such or such suggestion.

See you next time!
